informal_statement: What is the remainder when $5^{30}$ is divided by 7? Show that it is 1.
informal_proof:
Let us look at the powers of $5$: \begin{align*}
5^1 &\equiv 5 \pmod{7} \\
5^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{7} \\
5^3 &\equiv 6 \pmod{7} \\
5^4 &\equiv 2 \pmod{7} \\
5^5 &\equiv 3 \pmod{7} \\
5^6 &\equiv 1 \pmod{7}.
\end{align*} Since $5^6 \equiv 1 \pmod{7},$ we see that $5^{30} \equiv (5^6)^5 \equiv 1 \pmod{7},$ hence our desired remainder is $1.$
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)

theory mathd_numbertheory_229 
  imports Complex_Main "HOL-Computational_Algebra.Computational_Algebra"
  "HOL-Number_Theory.Number_Theory"
begin

theorem mathd_numbertheory_229:
  "(5^30) mod 7 = (1::nat)"
  sorry

end
